source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk2
evidence_span: The relationship between strain amplitude induced in the specimen and rod displacement was obtained using the finite element method code MARC (Fig. 2). The numerical results revealed that the maximum strain was induced at the width midpoint on the inner surface, marked by the point $M$ in the figure. Up to a total strain of about $0 . 6 \%$ , a linear relationship between the strain amplitude and rod displacement was obtained.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk2
evidence_span: Up to a total strain of about $0 . 6 \%$ , a linear relationship between the strain amplitude and rod displacement was obtained.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk2
evidence_span: Specimens were fatigue tested in a chamber in order to prevent oxidation or to get the effect of iodine pressure. Iodine gas was fed with inert gas into the test chamber through an iodine supplier with crystal iodine kept at a constant temperature. The saturated iodine vapor pressure at a temperature (e.g., $4 \ \mathbf { P a }$ at $2 7 3 \mathrm { ~ K ~ }$ ) was regarded as the partial pressure during test.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk4
evidence_span: Both for unirradiated and irradiated specimens, transgranular fracture surfaces were induced by the bending test. A ductile fracture surface was observed for unirradiated material, and neutron irradiation changed this surface into a typical brittle transgranular one.

evidence_span: Both for unirradiated and irradiated specimens, transgranular fracture surfaces were induced by the bending test. A ductile fracture surface was observed for unirradiated material, and neutron irradiation changed this surface into a typical brittle transgranular one.

evidence_span: We have checked the effect of surface oxidation using the Zry-2 with oxidized layers of 4 and $6 \mu \mathrm { m }$ at $6 2 3 \ \mathrm { K }$ . The oxidized specimen reduced the failure cycles to about one half of that for the reference.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk5
evidence_span: The results indicate that the fracture toughness decreases rapidly during the first few years of operation, but when the fluence reaches about $3 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } ~ \mathrm { { n } / \mathrm { { m } ^ { 2 } } }$ $\dot { \left( E \mathrm { ~ > ~ } 1 \mathrm { ~ M e V } \right. }$ the decrease in toughness slows down.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_018_chunk5
evidence_span: The post-irradiation toughness is not affected by either the initial mechanical properties or the difference in irradiation temperatures at the inlet and outlet of the fuel channel.
